lexUnit.name: put on.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: manipulate (a clothing or accoutrement) such that one ends up wearing it.

sentence.text: ` Can that be the frock you put on this morning ? "
The blokes all put on frocks , like , an' the chicks get togged up in strides .
So she put on her pretty frock and the scent that smells of yesterday and Hywel took the dogs in the van and she waited .
I was not , for once , wearing my battledress trousers , but had put on my uniform skirt with my battledress top .
She put on a straight yellow skirt , just brushing her knee , and a matching vest-top .
She put on a red petticoat first , then a black dress , and a white veil over the dress .
` The Irish fire-eater putting on a cocktail gown and tights to feed her mother 's social aspirations .

She put on her cloak and went downstairs .

He was putting on his heavy overcoat , asked again casually if he could have a look at the glass .
He had put on his overcoat and was pulling the collar up about his ears .

He put on his shirt and shorts and took my hand .

But she put on her new black knickers

` I put Martha 's apron on by accident this morning .
Quickly she put on lacy underwear and pulled her best dress from the wardrobe , a cocktail-length skirt of full , flame-coloured taffeta topped by a portrait-necked bodice of black velvet .
Without too much difficulty she put on fresh undies and a cotton shirt-waister , then sat in an easy chair by the open window to eat her lunch .
Then , feeling a strong urge to look at his portrait again , she showered quickly , put on clean undies and an oatmeal skirt and blouse , and made her way to the long gallery .
One time the doctor puts on rubber gloves and says something to Mum , and she goes out , leaving me sitting on the high bed , dangling my legs .

A moment later she put on her shoes .

He put on the spectacles and stood up .

He put on his glasses , walked over to the windows , and peered closely at the titles of the books .
